comment: “The Fine Oak” - Purchased Thanksgiving Eve 2016 and consumed Christmas 2017 - Peeps, Razzi, Mezz, Wolf, Sica and Ports.
One of the best I’ve ever had, incredible flavorful and so smooth. Very easy to drink neat

Ok, it is ok. Actually it is a little better than ok if you havent taste any other whiskies or dont care about tasting as the "sport" we "self proclaimed connoisseurs" often do. 

It is bottled at 40% abv, the color is yellow (actually it is jonquiripe corn) (i totally slayed this app with that term lol), and you can see water in its borders, not too much but it is there, taking points out of this dram.

On the nose is pleasant, not difficult or complex, with honey, butterscotch, butter, vanilla cream, nutty, and medicinal plants. You have to understand something, i have read that we humans percieve a range of aromas and one aroma or "note" can be 3 or 4 things for various people but really is one single note, that happens here. For me, the vanilla cream, butterscotch, butter, and honey is the same note that tricks my brain into percieving 4 diferent things, but actually that is one note. I think i read this somewhere and now i know what they (the writer) was talking about.

It might sound to you that the nose should be awesome but it really is fair. nice notes but nothing too breathtaking.

On the palate is more interesting, starts sweet with honey and caramel notes, to change into this FINE WOOD flavor. Actually the name of this whisky is Fine Oak, and that is exactly how it feels, as tasting some new, young, piece of wood, my brain tells me (strangely) that this feels as if my new furniture with its new colors has become whisky. Excuse me for my crazyness when describing but i believe that is the true intention of writing this reviews, to tell you what this whisky makes me feel or remember. 

While getting the fine wood note, you will feel the trademark spicyness from The Macallan. Macallan can be easily detected by any Macallan drinker in a blindfolded tasting, because its spicy flavor is very characteristic. 

The finish is long and for the first time i felt a whisky which is mouth watering. it is better on the palate than on the nose, i believe the weakest part is that it is light bodied, and actually is too easy to drink, very smooth, makes it not too appealing. 

Overall it is a better whisky than most 10 year old ones, and the brand name is always elegant so give it a try.
Very drinkable; a little sweet, smooth, and nothing really overpowering. I'm looking for a scotch with a little more. . . masculinity.

Possessed of pleasing citrus notes making for a nice dram. MacAllan has not tried to hide or even mellow the dominant wood note and some may feel they are "tasting the cask" too much; however, mellower and less woody single malts are plentiful, leaving Macallan Fine Oak 10 as a distinct taste and aroma experience worth trying.

Great biscuit and citrus notes with just enough spice to give it more than just a one trick pony.  This is a scotch for your friends whose palates need some growth or for ones who prefer more bourbon than single malt.
Has an amaretto flavor and scent. Overly sweet and only a little richness. A slight spiciness, but nothing overpowering. Given the cost, there are probably better options.
The oak is ok. Port barreled is better
God smak, men også lite smak. Kjedelig. Lettdrikkelig.
Light and fruity taste. Slightly sweet with a smokey underbite.
Oily mouth feel and dry finish. Woodsy taste with almond. Spiced vanilla smell. Needs water to tone down the heat.
Smooth, not too oily - clean finish
Birthday gift from my brother. First tried it at his place.
My least favorite of all of Macallan's collection. Not a big fan of any of the fine oak series. Too much wood not enough flavor. However aging does help, but then again it always does.
Nose is sliced yellow apples and citrus.  Taste is slightly tart with a mid-range dark tone. This is very similar to Johnnie Walker Red but a bit more refined.
The nose is soft & light, mildly sweet fruits & marzipan. A little light heather smoke, maybe. Medium body, still sweet, almond shortbreads. Long, tingling finish. Not bad at all.
Sweet Maple and citrus nose, spicy wood palate, nice finish
Subtle woody flavors, a but muted after awhile but quite drinkable

Noses like apple marzipan. Goes in slightly sweet, with a good bit of oak. Finishes out sorta rapidly, but with a burn. Water helps the burn, but don't overdo it -- you don't want oak juice. Almost a disappointment for the name, but as a drink, it's about as drinkable as the white wine it looks like.
I felt like the flavor on this whiskey was pretty flat, not a whole lot of excitement or dominating tastes. I prefer their 12 year by a long ways
Love it!!!! ..smooth, fruity, notes of honey.
Honey, vanilla, and a little spice. sweet and smooth after a splash of water
Sweet butter and maple on the nose with a rich, baked taste and a hint of chocolate. The finish is warm but short.
This is a really nice light whisky. If you have friends who have only had peaty, or woody scotches give them this to try. There's nice sweet citrus flavors.
Warm butterscotch aroma, oak and vanilla flavor leads to subtle floral notes.
This doesn't hold a candle to anything else in the range.  Carries the Macallan house style, but is honestly not that much better than something I would shoot at a bar.

Nice and smooth.  It worked very well as a palate cleanser at the bourbon & scotch tasting earlier.  I could see myself settling in with this on movie night, too.  Very "crushable" (if I may borrow a bit of craft beer terminology).
This is a very good starter scotch.  Sweeter profile with not much burn.  Easy drinker.
Solid 4. Nose is macallan and hard to distinguish anything else. It's like a sweet oak taste with some sheryy. Very good. Does leave the tongue numb from spicyness or burn
Smooth and complex enough to enjoy
Good combo of complexity but simple. Solid but not worth a whole bottle solo. Good for parties or gifts.
Puckering strong oak flavor with a quick fading after taste
Good clean flavor. Wish it had 3 more years in the barrel.
Good flavor but a little rough

Sitting at the Rod 'n Reel again to close another college year move-in.  Decided on this since Jameson 18 was empty. Nose is light of honey, a tinge of tangerine and walnuts and a bit of floral. The body is soft and arrives with sweet vanilla and honey and very little else.  Finishes slightly spicy of black pepper and a touch of is oak and drying tannins.  Nothing too special. It's safe, sweet, unsophisticated and easy to sip. Good as a summer sipper but I would go elsewhere something more.  [Tasted:8/28/16][85/100]
Sweet, note of vanilla, really smooth. But for the money, I'd like to get Macallan 12 instead. This scotch is not as rich and delicate as 12.
Peppery aroma. Smooth and delicate complex flavour from triple cask ageing. As a newer Scotch drinker, this single malt whiskey was very pleasant and surprisingly smooth. Very enjoyable !
Gets 5 stars, fantastic scotch for a ten year old and simple and enjoyable to drink!
Far underrated. For a $50 scotch, this one kills it and is far better than the 12 year.
Sweet, fruity, apple, floral. Very niceee
Smells of aged pairs, slightly burnt caramel, strong burn to it, prefer with Ginger Ale in a Highball where it takes a Apple Juice character and sweet finish.

A curious find at an out-of-the-way liquor store--side-by-side with Macallan's new non-age-stated entry level Gold. And for $15 less, to boot! I've never been a particular partisan for the Macallan (it's always seemed more like a status symbol than a scotch to be drunk), but felt like it was a sign from above. And the whisky is itself nice, if not setting the world on fire. Smell is honey, melon, lemon, heather/lavender, vanilla. Faint red fruits, spongecake. Taste arrives soft--no kick to speak of--and delivers lots of melon (cantaloupe! honeydew!), lemon, honey, and a slightly indistinct floral character. The dry, woodsy finish is blink-and-you-miss-it short, but the overall experience is quite pleasant. Not mad at the purchase, though I'm not particular mad that it's gone from the shelves either.
Very sweet and fruity. Spicy but smooth. Malty finish.
Lovely summer patio dram. Sadly these age statements are slowly getting phased out.
great 'budget' drink. v v smooth and had good oak taste for sure. neat was great
sample/a lot to like here though price point is high; oak takes front and center stage with easy burnt toast finish

Nose has lots of citrus, pear, dark chocolate bitter sourness.  Color is very light.
Palate has a lot going on, excellent flavor progression from the first hard hit to the long enduring finish which makes you want more.  I like it a lot, not enough to buy often though.  Going to drink this one slowly.
Tasted at The Rosendale, Providence RI 12/27/18

Nose: Caramel, apple, banana
Palate: Chocolate, caramel, sherry, brown sugar
Finish: Peppery, minty
Similar mouth feel to the 12 but clearly younger and not as sweet/smooth

Very thin and very light. Nose has lots of oak, a little maple, vanilla, banana and a nice nose tingling mix of heat and pepper spice. Taste is the same as the nose here, sweet, then peppery and with a surprising amount of heat, showing it’s youth. Finish is the best part, nice, long and spicy. It’s good, just not my preference in a scotch, almost feels more like identity crisis rather than complex. Water completely ruins this pour.
Light, fresh, fruity, milk chocolate and light toffee finish.  A well balanced everyday scotch with an impressive flavor.

Solid. Soft. 
Fun with ice and orange peel.

I recently stumbled upon this one for $55. And while I assumed that this would not be a particularly great value, curiosity got the better of me. This one was a core component of the Macallan portfolio until it was recently discontinued, seemingly replaced by the NAS double cask Gold Edition. Let's see if Macallan made a mistake or were right to let this one die off.

Nose: Floral, fruity, sweet, and "perfumey." Standard Speyside notes of vanilla, honey, toffee, malt, and apple. There are also the classic Macallan date, plum, fig notes, evidence of sherry cask aging (no leather notes, surprisingly). Notes of caramel, butterscotch, walnut, hazelnut, and dense oak aromas suggest bourbon barrel presence. Decent.

Palate: Sweet, light, floral, fruity. More apple, vanilla, toffee, honey, caramel. Walnut and hazelnut as well. There are now distinct notes of zesty orange, milk chocolate, and truffle. Maybe even a slight pineapple to compliment the orange citrus. Reminiscent of the 15, just not quite as impressive. Nevertheless, it's tasty. Sherry notes are largely the same, plum, fig, raisin, date. But despite the presence of this darker notes, this drinks as a lighter Speyside. The lower percentage of sherry casks used in the Fine Oak line causes this to deviate from traditional Macallan.

Finish: Moderate in length. Here, it's completely oak driven. Cinnamon and baking spice. Quality oak. Lighter notes of vanilla and honey persist. It's perfectly pleasant, but lacking. 40% ABV was not the right choice here. 43 likely would've made a considerable improvement to what is an acceptable but unremarkable finish.

And here we are. Middle of the road. Nothing really to write home about. I'd never complain about receiving a pour of what I'd consider a decent whisky, but you also won't find me lobbying Macallan/Edrington for the dismissal of this one from the lineup.

Everything that this one does, the 15 year does much better. It's deeper, richer, and more refined. The extra 5 years and 3% ABV do wonders for this one. Even though it's almost double the price, it's a much better VFM. This would've been a solid deal at $40 or less, but at $55, I've gotten both 12s for less. And those statements end any discussion on the merit of keeping this one around, at least for me.

It's a shame to see an age-stated staple disappear, but I won't cry over spilled Macallan. Not this one at least.

Two months have passed since my first tasting of this whiskey. Two months of me sharpening my tasting skills (hopefully) and two months the whiskey has been oxidizing in a bottle that’s about 7/8th full. Time to revisit and see if I notice any differences.
Nose: I get fruity, chocolaty sherry, orange peels and some astringency.
Palate: Creamy, smooth, oily, chocolate, sherry and oak.
Finish: Starts pleasant enough but turns a little bitter, good thing it’s short.
I definitely enjoyed this more the second time around.
oak, sherry and toffee on the nose and palate, short spicy finish. splash of water smooths and mellows everything.
I’d give a 3.5. Light but predominantly Oakey. Decent.
Light sweet nose. Sweet oaky flavor with sherry notes. Oaky sherry finish and lingering flavor.
Nose is oaky and lightly sweet with notes of maple or perhaps honey, maybe a hint of citrus. Palate has some spice, lightly fruity, a bit of pear. Finish is smooth. Oak notes all the way through.

Nose: oak, a medicinal quality, slightly sweet, green moss
Palate: strong oakiness, vegetal qualities
Finish: short, oaky
This is a really smooth drink
Oily, sweet, spicy. Pleasant burn. Not much of an aftertaste.
Very lean, a little bit of vanilla. Good for a 10 Year old whisky.
Smooth for a 10y, not much in the notes tho.
Decent smooth non peaty dram. Rich and full in the mouth sweet, very slight peppery note
Decent smooth non peaty dram. Rich and full in the mouth sweet, very slight peppery note
Sweet and smooth. A little peat at the end that keeps things interesting
